Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish beca

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves.

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves.

They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actully very low. You do not hear too m

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actully very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying w

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actully very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sp

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying dri

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or g

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is se

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer i

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those act

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves.

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those el

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partakin

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any aciticty is. I d

They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any aciticty is. I do not like anyting is in

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any aciticty is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unle

For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any aciticty is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposeful

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any aciticty is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of your

All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  De

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Ded

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Decdiding to do one of these activities is n

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Decdiding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone e

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Decdiding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directl

Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.

They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish. 
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anyting is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Decdiding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.  
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.
 Wh

I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.  
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.

Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.  
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.  
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.
 When you are prepared and understand the risks, just hav

For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.  
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.
 When you are prepared and understand the risks, just have fun and not worry

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.
 When you are prepared and understand the risks, just have fun and not worry, you are not being selfish at all.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, while these activities are really dangerous, I do not think it is selfish for people to pursue them. They are freely deciding to partake in the activity and almost all sports already have an inherent risk of injury that comes along with them. Most, if not all of these sports that are considered more dangerous require you sign a waiver in addition to getting trained before doing anything actually dangerous. For example, rock climbing in my area requires you to train and then pass a test before you are allowed to go off on your own at any of the gyms. Because of this, the person is trained and understands the risks. I do not consider this selfish because they are just doing with their life what they want to do. Partaking in the sport does not directly impact anyone else other than themselves. 

While these sports are dangerous, the chance of injury is actually very low. You do not hear too much about someone dying while skydiving or rock climbing. The only time you hear about someone dying while doing these activities is when it is a freak accident which can occur in any sport really.

Calling participating in a sport selfish would be like saying driving a car is selfish. Or going swimming is selfish. Or drinking a beer is selfish. All of those activities are statistically more likely to cause harm to the person doing it but no one would consider any of those activities as selfish.  
I think that it is a personal decision to partake in these activities., just like partaking in any activity is. I do not like anything is inherently selfish unless you are purposefully forgoing others for the sake of yourself.  Deciding to do one of these activities is not forgoing anyone else and only directly affects you. That is why I do not find these type of things selfish. 
I think that if you are going to do one of these activities, you should be well trained and understand the risks.
 When you are prepared and understand the risks, just have fun and not worry, you are not being selfish at all.
